contextId.information: Setting their thrones "against all the walls that surround it" represents commanding their armies to destroy the walls surrounding Jerusalem. AT: "and they will command their armies to destroy the walls surrounding Judah" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: against all the walls that surround it

contextId.information: This represents all the people of the land. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: the whole land

contextId.information: The word "house" is a metonym for the family that lives in the house. In this case it refers to Israel's descendants, who had become the nation of Israel. AT: "the Israelites" or "the Israelite people group" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: the house of Israel

contextId.information: This expression refers to God himself, who is glorious. AT: "their glorious God" or "me, your glorious God" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: their glory

contextId.information: Here "born in his master's home" is metonym for being born into slavery. AT: "Was he born a slave" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: Was he born in his master's home

contextId.information: This represents destroying the land in such a way that people will feel horror when they see it. AT: "and destroyed Israel's land" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: and made his land a horror

contextId.information: The word "house" is a metonym for the family that lives in the house. In this case it refers to Israel's descendants. Translate as in [[:en:bible:notes:jer:02:04|2:4]]. AT: "the Israelites" or "the Israelite people group" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: the house of Israel

contextId.information: Here "tree" and "stone" represent idols carved from wood and stone. These words emphasize that the idol was made of ordinary things and is not worthy of worship. AT: "These people are the ones who say to a carved piece of wood, "You are my father," and to a carved stone, "You gave birth to me." " (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: These are the ones who say to the tree, 'You are my father,' and to the stone, 'You gave birth to me.'

contextId.information: Here "your eyes" represents looking at something. AT: "Look up" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: Lift up your eyes

contextId.information: Here "listened" represents obeying, and "my voice" represents what God has said. AT: "you have not obeyed what I have said" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: you have not listened to my voice

contextId.information: Here "heart" represents Yahweh's desire or will. The phrase "after my heart" is an idiom that describes people who do God's will. AT: "shepherds who do my will" or "shepherds who do what I want" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: shepherds after my heart

contextId.information: Here "Yahweh's throne" represents where Yahweh rules from. AT: "This is where Yahweh rules from" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: This is Yahweh's throne

contextId.information: The word "house" is a metonym for the family that lives in the house. In this case it refers to the kingdom of Judah, which included the descendants of Judah and Benjamin. Translate as in [[:en:bible:notes:jer:11:09|11:10]]. AT: "Judah" or "the kingdom of Judah" or "the people of Judah" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: the house of Judah

contextId.information: The word "house" is a metonym for the family that lives in the house. In this case it refers to the kingdom of Israel. Translate as in [[:en:bible:notes:jer:03:17|3:18]]. AT: "Israel" or "the kingdom of Israel" or "the people of Israel" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: the house of Israel

contextId.information: "If you will come back to me, people of Israel or "If you will change your behavior, people of Israel" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: If you return, Israel

contextId.information: The sword represents all of the different weapons that people use in war. AT: "They will use their weapons to conquer your strong cities." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: They will batter down with a sword your fortified cities

contextId.information: AT: "is stubborn and rebellious." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: has a stubborn heart

contextId.information: "The children in the streets" stands for all children in the city. AT: "Express my anger to the children in the city" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: Pour it out on the children in the streets

contextId.information: AT: "Hear, people that live on the earth." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: Hear, earth

contextId.information: Here pouring out innocent blood represents killing those not deserving death. AT: "kill innocent people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: pour out innocent blood

contextId.information: Here walking after is a metonym for following after with the intent to serve and obey. Translate this as you did in [[:en:bible:notes:jer:07:05|7:6]]. AT: "serve other gods" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: walk after other gods

contextId.information: This is a metonym for Yahweh's temple. It can be expressed in active form. Translate this as you did in [[:en:bible:notes:jer:07:08|7:10]]. AT: "this house that belongs to me" or "this temple where you worship me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: this house that is called by my name

contextId.information: "in my sight" or "in my thoughts" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: in my eye

contextId.information: AT: "people getting married (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: the sounds of the groom and the bride

contextId.information: Israel as a daughter. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: daughter of my people

contextId.information: AT: "they do not pay attention to the things I tell them." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: they do not listen to my voice

contextId.information: AT: "I will send an army of soldiers to fight against them." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: I will send out a sword after them

contextId.information: An uncircumcised heart represents the character of a person that does not obey Yahweh's laws. AT: "and all the people of Israel have not kept the covenant with Yahweh by obeying him." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: and all the house of Israel has an uncircumcised heart

contextId.information: AT: "Punish the people of the nations severely" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: Pour your fury on the nations

contextId.information: Here what Yahweh says is represented by his "voice." AT: "Listen to what I say" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: Listen to my voice

contextId.information: Here Yahweh's "voice" represents what he says. AT: "Listen to what I say" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: Listen to my voice

contextId.information: The word "house" is a metonym for the family that lives in the house. In this case it refers to the kingdom of Israel. Translate as in [[:en:bible:notes:jer:02:04|2:4]]. AT: "Israel" or "The kingdom of Israel" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: The house of Israel

contextId.information: The word "house" is a metonym for the family that lives in the house. In this case it refers to the kingdom of Judah, which included the descendants of Judah and Benjamin. Translate as in [[:en:bible:notes:jer:11:09|11:10]]. AT: "Judah" or "the kingdom of Judah" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: the house of Judah

contextId.information: The word "house" is a metonym for the family that lives in the house. In this case it refers to the kingdom of Israel. Translate as in [[:en:bible:notes:jer:02:04|2:4]]. AT: "Israel" or "the kingdom of Israel" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: the house of Israel

contextId.information: The word "house" is a metonym for the family that lives in the house. In this case it refers to the kingdom of Judah, which included the descendants of Judah and Benjamin. Translate as in [[:en:bible:notes:jer:11:09|11:10]]. AT: "Judah" or "the kingdom of Judah" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: the house of Judah

contextId.information: The heart is a metonym for what a person feelings and desires and "the mind" is a metonym for what a person thinks and decides. AT: "a person's feelings and thoughts" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: the heart and the mind

contextId.information: Here the "sword" represents battle. AT: "will die in battle" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: will die by the sword

contextId.information: Here the "heart" represents a person's thoughts and true feelings. AT: "my thoughts" or "my inner feelings" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: my heart

contextId.information: The word "house" is a metonym for the family that lives in the house. In this case it refers to the kingdom of Judah, which included the descendants of Judah and Benjamin. Translate as in [[:en:bible:notes:jer:11:09|11:10]]. AT: "Judah" or "the kingdom of Judah" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: the house of Judah

contextId.information: Here Judah and Jerusalem refer to the people who there. AT: "of the people of Judah and Jerusalem" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: of Judah and Jerusalem

contextId.information: The word "house" is a metonym for the family that lives in the house. In this case it refers to the kingdom of Israel. Translate as in [[:en:bible:notes:jer:03:17|3:18]]. AT: "Israel" or "the kingdom of Israel" or "the people of Israel" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: the house of Israel

contextId.information: The word "house" is a metonym for the family that lives in the house. In this case it refers to the kingdom of Judah, which included the descendants of Judah and Benjamin. Translate as in [[:en:bible:notes:jer:03:17|03:18]]. AT: "Judah" or "the kingdom of Judah" or "the people of Judah" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: the house of Judah

contextId.information: Here the throne that the king of Judah sits on is represented as "David's throne." AT: "the kings who sit on Judah's throne" or "the kings of the nation of Judah" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: the kings who sit on David's throne

contextId.information: Here "Judah" represents the people who live there. This can be stated in active form. AT: "The enemies will take the people of Judah captive, they will take all of her people into exile" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: Judah will be taken captive, all of her into exile

contextId.information: Here "sword" stands for warfare, and "see" stands for "experience" or "suffer." AT: "You will not experience any war" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: You will not see sword

contextId.information: Here "name" stands for the idea of authority. AT: "prophesying while claiming my authority to do so" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] )
contextId.quote: prophesying in my name

contextId.information: Here the word "hand" refers to power and authority. The two phrases mean basically the same thing and emphasize Yahweh's great power. AT: "my great power." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
contextId.quote: my hand and my power

contextId.information: Here the word "heart" refers to the minds and thoughts of people. AT: "The human mind is more deceitful" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: The heart is more deceitful

contextId.information: AT: "murdered many innocent people in this place" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: filled this place with innocent blood

contextId.information: Here the word "mind" refers to Yahweh's thoughts. AT: "nor did I ever think about it" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: nor did it enter my mind

contextId.information: AT: "I will make their enemies kill them with swords" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: I will make them to fall by the sword before their enemies

contextId.information: Possible meanings are 1) that Pashhur himself beat Jeremiah or 2) that Pashhur ordered other men to beat Jeremiah. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: Pashhur beat Jeremiah

contextId.information: AT: "their enemies will kill them with swords" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: they will fall by the sword of their enemies

contextId.information: Here the word "hand" refers to power. AT: "I will enable the king of Babylon to conquer all of Judah" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: I will give all of Judah into the hand of the king of Babylon

contextId.information: AT: "who knows what people think and desire" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: who see the mind and the heart

contextId.information: Possible meanings are 1) the instruments of war refers to the soldiers who carry them and "hand" represents control. AT: "the soldiers that you command" or 2) the instruments of war are literal weapons and "your hand" represent both the king and his soldiers. AT: "the weapons that you and your soldiers carry" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: the instruments of war that are in your hand

contextId.information: Here "hand" refers to the power of their enemies over them. AT: "into the power" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: into the hand

contextId.information: Possible meanings are 1) this is a metonym for death in battle. AT: "in battle" or 2) they will be killed by literal swords. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: with the edge of the sword

contextId.information: This refers to death in battle. AT: "in battle" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: by the sword

contextId.information: Here "hand" represents the power of the king to destroy the city. AT: "into the power of the king" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: into the hand of the king

contextId.information: The word "house" is a metonym for the family that lives in the house. In this case it refers to the royal descendants of that kings. AT: "descendants of the king of Judah" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: the house of the king of Judah

contextId.information: This refers to the city that was located on a rocky plain. This is also a metonym for the people who live in that city. AT: "you people who live on the rocky plain" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: rock of the plain

contextId.information: This refers to having authority as king, like David had. AT: "rule as king, like David before you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: sit on David's throne

contextId.information: This refers to kings having authority like David had. AT: "kings, ruling like David before them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: kings sitting on David's throne

contextId.information: This phrase describes the kings as powerful and wealthy. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: riding in a chariot and on horses

contextId.information: Possible meanings are 1) this here refers to the royal palace there the king lived or 2) "house" is a metonym for the family that lives in the house, who were the royal line of the kings of Judah. AT: "the royal dynasty of Judah" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: the house of the king of Judah

contextId.information: The word "house" is a metonym for the family that lives in the house. In this case it refers to King Jehoiakim and his family. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: his house

contextId.information: Here "eyes" is a metonym for seeing and "heart" is a metonym for thinking. AT: "you never look for or think about anything except ... crushing of others" or "you only look for and think about ways to crush others and pour out innocent blood, and to oppress and crush others" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: there is nothing in your eyes and heart except worry ... crushing of others

contextId.information: This is a wordplayâ€”Yahweh uses the idea of "shepherd" in two different ways. Here "shepherds" is a metonym for the leaders of Jerusalem, and the wind "leads" them away. The wind represents Yahweh.  AT: "I will take your leaders away if if the wind had blown them away" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: The wind will shepherd away all your shepherds

contextId.information: A signet ring was used by a king to place his seal of authority on documents. The signet ring therefore represents authority to rule. The right hand also represents authority to rule. AT: "the signet ring on my right hand that represented my authority to be king" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: the signet on my right hand

contextId.information: Sitting on a throne is a metonym for ruling as king. AT: "become king" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: sit on David's throne

contextId.information: The prophet's heart is broken and bones are trembling because he is afraid of the judgment that will result from the lies of the false prophets. AT: "I have great fear for what will happen because of the false prophets" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: Regarding the prophets, my heart is broken in me, and all of my bones tremble

contextId.information: Here Yahweh's temple is compared to a house, a place where Yahweh is said to live among his people. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: in my house

contextId.information: AT: "I will send enemy armies" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: I will send out sword

contextId.information: AT: "you have not obeyed me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: you have not listened to me

contextId.information: Here "pastures" stands for the entire nation. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: So the peaceful pastures will be devastated

contextId.information: "with the authority of Yahweh our God" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: in the name of Yahweh our God

contextId.information: Ahikam supported Jeremiah and protected him. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: the hand of Ahikam

contextId.information: This refers to one of David's descendants. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: serve David their king

contextId.information: AT: "I am about to cause the descendants of Jacob to prosper and I will have compassion on them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: I am about to bring back the fortunes of Jacob's tents and have compassion on his homes

contextId.information: Jeremiah speaks of himself as if he were the people of Israel. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: Yahweh appeared to me

contextId.information: Ephraim was the ancestor of the largest tribe in Israel. His name is a metonym for the people of Israel. AT: "I have certainly heard the descendants of Ephraim sorrowing" or "I have certainly heard the people of Israel sorrowing" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: I have certainly heard Ephraim sorrowing

contextId.information: The name of the man Judah is a metonym for his descendants, the people of the tribe of Judah, and the cities of Judah are spoken of as if they were the family of the man Judah, all of them living "there," in the land of Judah. AT: "it will be as if the land were a house in which Judah lived with his family" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Judah and all his cities will live together there

contextId.information: The word "house" is a metonym for the family that lives in the house, in this case the people of Israel and the people of Judah. The house in turn is spoken of as if it were a field in which Yahweh would sow seed, and people and the animals they raise for food, milk, and skins are spoken of as if they are that seed. AT: "I will cause the people of Israel and Judah to become many people with many animals" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I will sow the houses of Israel and Judah with the descendants of man and beast

contextId.information: The word "house" is a metonym for the family that lives in the house. In this case it refers to the kingdom of Judah, which included the descendants of Judah and Benjamin. Translate as in [[:en:bible:notes:jer:11:09|11:10]]. AT: "Judah" or "the kingdom of Judah" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: the house of Judah

contextId.information: The word "house" is a metonym for the family that lives in the house. In this case it refers to the kingdom of Israel. Translate as in [[:en:bible:notes:jer:02:04|2:4]]. AT: "Israel" or "the kingdom of Israel" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: the house of Israel

contextId.information: It might be best to translate so that the reader understands that other people helped Zedekiah do this. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: Zedekiah king of Judah had imprisoned him

contextId.information: The phrase "raised arm" is a metonym for the strength of the arm, so the words "your great strength" and "your raised arm" form a doublet. AT: "by your great power" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
contextId.quote: by your great strength and with your raised arm

contextId.information: The word "guilt" is a metonym for Yahweh punishing people because they are guilty of doing evil things. Yahweh punishing people is spoken of as if he were pouring a large container full of liquid or small objects into people's laps as they sit. AT: "and you punish children for the sin of their parents" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: and pour the guilt of men into the laps of their children after them

contextId.information: Open eyes are a metonym for what the person sees. How a person lives is spoken of as if he were walking on a path. AT: "You see everything that people do" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: for your eyes are open to all the ways of people

contextId.information: Here "name" refers to God's reputation. AT: "you have made yourself famous" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: you have made your name famous

contextId.information: The phrase "strong hand" is a metonym for strength, and the phrase "raised arm" is a metonym for the strength of the arm, so the phrases "strong hand" and "raised arm" form a doublet. AT: "by your great strength" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
contextId.quote: with a strong hand, with a raised arm

contextId.information: Yahweh speaks of the city as if it were a small object that he could put into a person's hand. The word "hand" is a metonym for the power that the hand puts into action. AT: "put this city under the power of the Chaldeans" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: give this city into the hand of the Chaldeans

contextId.information: Possible meanings are 1) "doing what I consider evil" or 2) "doing evil knowing that I am watching" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: doing evil before my eyes

contextId.information: Here "mind" refers to Yahweh's thoughts. AT: "I never thought at all" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: It never entered my mind

contextId.information: Here "hand" means power or control. This can be translated in active form. AT: "Yahweh has given it to the king of Babylon" or "Yahweh has given the king of Babylon the power to rule it" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: It is given into the hand of the king of Babylon

contextId.information: The people of Israel will want to work together to honor Yahweh. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: one heart and one way to honor me

contextId.information: The word "song" is a metonym for the object about which people will sing the song. AT: "something about which all the people groups of the earth will sing songs of praise and honor to me, Yahweh" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: a song of praise and honor for all the nations of the earth

contextId.information: The word "house" is a metonym for the family that lives in the house. In this case it refers to the kingdom of Judah, which included the descendants of Judah and Benjamin. Translate as in [[:en:bible:notes:jer:11:09|11:10]]. AT: "Judah" or "the kingdom of Judah" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: the house of Judah

contextId.information: These towns' names are metonyms for the people who live in the towns. AT: "the people of Judah ... the people of Jerusalem" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: Judah ... Jerusalem

contextId.information: The throne is a metonym for the king. AT: "to be king over the house of Israel" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: to sit on the throne of the house of Israel

contextId.information: The word "house" is a metonym for the family that lives in the house. In this case it refers to the kingdom of Israel. Translate as in [[:en:bible:notes:jer:02:04|2:4]]. AT: "Israel" or "the kingdom of Israel" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: the house of Israel

contextId.information: The throne is a metonym for the king who sits on the throne. AT: "to rule the kingdom I have given to him", (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: to sit on his throne

contextId.information: Sight is a metonym for thinking. AT: "they no longer think of my people as a nation" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: my people ... are no longer a nation in their sight

contextId.information: This refers to all the towns around Jerusalem. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: and all of her cities

contextId.information: Here the word "hand" is a metonym for the control that the hand exercises. AT: "under the control of the king of Babylon." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: into the hand of the king of Babylon

contextId.information: The word "sword" is a metonym for dying in war. AT: "You will not die in battle" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: You will not die by the sword.

contextId.information: "message" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: word

contextId.information: To incline the ear, to lean the head toward the speaker so as to hear better, is a metonym for paying attention to what the speaker is saying. AT: "did not ... pay attention to what I said" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: did not ... incline their ears to me

contextId.information: "Eyes" here is a metonym for someone's opinion or idea. AT: "what I consider to be right" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: right in my eyes

contextId.information: This can be translated in active form. AT: "the house that belongs to me" or "the building in which they worship me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]] [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: the house that is called by my name

contextId.information: The word "voice" is a metonym for the command that Jonadab spoke. AT: "the command of Jonadab" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: the voice of Jonadab

contextId.information: Weak hands are a metonym for a person who is afraid. AT: "he is causing the soldiers and all the people in the city to lose courage" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: he is weakening the hands of the fighting men who remain in this city, and the hands of all the people

contextId.information: The hand is a metonym for the power that the hand exercises. AT:"you are able do whatever you want with him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: he is in your hand

contextId.information: Here the word "hand" refers to the men's control or power. AT: "I will not ... allow those men to capture you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: I will not ... give you into the hand of those men

contextId.information: AT: "God of the people of Israel" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: God of Israel

contextId.information: AT: "will not escape from their power" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: will not escape from their hand

contextId.information: Here "hand" refers to the king's power or his army. AT: "The army of the king of Babylon will capture you and will burn the city" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: You will be captured by the hand of the king of Babylon, and this city will be burned

contextId.information: "Eyes" here is a metonym for someone's opinion or idea. AT: "it is what you consider to be right" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: it is good in your eyes

contextId.information: "you think it is good" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: it is good in your eyes

contextId.information: Here "voice" represents what Yahweh says. AT: "what Yahweh our God says" or "we will obey Yahweh our God" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: the voice of Yahweh our God

contextId.information: Here the word "hand" refers to power and authority. AT: "rescue you from his power" or "rescue you from him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: rescue you from his hand

contextId.information: Here "voice" represents a command. To not obey is like the people did not hear Yahweh's command. AT: "if you do not obey my commands, even though I am Yahweh, your God." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: if you do not listen to my voice, the voice of Yahweh your God

contextId.information: Being hungry for food is used to describe famine. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: we will not go hungry for food

contextId.information: Here "the sword" represents war. The Israelites experiencing war even if they go to Egypt is spoken of as if the sword would chase after the people catch up with them. AT: "you will experience the terrible results of war" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
contextId.quote: the sword that you fear will overtake you

contextId.information: Here "hand" represents power or control. AT: "to give us over to the Chaldeans" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: to deliver us into the hand of the Chaldeans

contextId.information: Both the king's "throne" and "pavilion" are used to refer to his royal authority. AT: "I will cause him to rule as king over the people of Egypt. He will place his throne and pavilion over these stones you have buried" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: I will place his throne over these stones that you, Jeremiah, have buried. Nebuchadnezzar will place his pavilion over them

contextId.information: Here "fall" means to die. And "sword" represents the enemies carrying weapons. AT: "Enemies will kill some of them and others will die of hunger" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: They will fall by sword and famine

contextId.information: Here "Jerusalem" represents the people. AT: "I punished the people of Jerusalem" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: I punished Jerusalem

contextId.information: Here "sword" represents enemies carrying weapons. AT: "by causing enemies to kill some of them, others starved to death, and others died because of disease" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: with sword, famine, and plague

contextId.information: Here "in Yahweh's name" means "in Yahweh's authority" or "as Yahweh's representative." AT: "We will not obey this message that you say Yahweh told you to tell us" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: About the word that you have told us in Yahweh's nameâ€”we will not listen to you

contextId.information: Here "sword" represents enemies carrying weapons. AT: "enemy soldiers were killing some of us and some of us were dying of hunger" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: were dying by sword and famine

contextId.information: Here "voice" refers to Yahweh's commands. AT: "you would not obey his commands" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: you would not listen to his voice

contextId.information: Here "Judah" represents the people. AT: "all the people of Judah" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: all of Judah

contextId.information: Here "Judah" represents the people. AT: "all the people of Judah" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: all of Judah

contextId.information: Yahweh's "great name" refers to his whole being and reputation. AT: "I have sworn upon myself" or "I have sworn by speaking my powerful name" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: I have sworn by my great name

contextId.information: Here "name" represents the whole being of Yahweh. And, "mouth" represents the whole person. This can be stated in active form. AT: "No person of Judah living in the land of Egypt will ever call upon me again" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: My name will no longer be called upon by the mouths of any of the men of Judah in all the land of Egypt

contextId.information: Here "hand" represents power or control. And, Nebuchadnezzar represents his whole army. The phrase "sought his life" is an idiom that means to want to kill someone. AT: "when I allowed the army of Nebuchadnezzar to defeat Zedekiah king of Judah"  (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: when I gave Zedekiah king of Judah into the hand of Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon, his enemy who sought his life

contextId.information: AT: "Unspoiled people of Egypt". (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: virgin daughter of Egypt

contextId.information: This is one of the chief gods of Egypt. Here "Apis" represents "strength you trust" (UDB) of the nation of Egypt. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: Apis

contextId.information: "Amon" is the king of the Egyptian gods. "Thebes" is the capital of Egypt, and here represents the entire Egyptian empire. AT: "Amon, god over all of Egypt" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
contextId.quote: Amon of Thebes

contextId.information: These two phrases mean the same thing. Together they strengthen the encouragement to the people of Judah not to be afraid. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: my servant Jacob, do not fear. Do not be dismayed, Israel

contextId.information: This phrase refers to the army from the north which Yahweh is using to punish the Philistines. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: sword of Yahweh

contextId.information: This refers to the people of Moab. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: Her children

contextId.information: "Chemosh" is the chief god of the Moabites. Here "Chemosh" represents the nation of Moab. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: Chemosh

contextId.information: AT: "Their fine young men will all be slaughtered." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: its finest young men have gone down to the place of slaughter.

contextId.information: AT: "experience punishment" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: drink some of the cup

contextId.information: "are happy and wealthy" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: live by many streams of water

contextId.information: AT: "You Babylonians will certainly see" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: in your sight

contextId.information: Yahweh promises such great upheaval that the whole nation will tremble. The "land" represents the people of Babylon living there. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: the land will shake

contextId.information: "Daughter of Babylon" is another name for the residents of Babylon. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: The daughter of Babylon

contextId.information: This states in another way the previous idea that Babylon has taken everything from Israel. "Food" represents all the good things there before. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: He filled his stomach with my good food.

contextId.information: Bel was the main god of the Babylonians and represents the whole country and the people that worshiped it. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: I will punish Bel
